nodes.bodyText: [style] Instead of aligned end of line comments, we place comments above the field.
No problem.  Updating.
I'm pretty sure this and responseMap can be final.
Will get rid of responseMap, per your rewrite of the document parsing.
Make a defensive copy with ImmutableSet.copyOf(config.getOrgSet())

check not null:
this.httpClient = requireNonNull(httpClient, "httpClient is null");
Nice!  Should work.

I suggest renaming this to allowedOrganization and then we can remove the comment as the usage is obvious.  Also, we generally try to avoid abbreviations, because they can be difficult for non-native speakers to understand.  In the case "org" is pretty common, so it wouldn't necessary need a change, but I think allowedOrganization is much more understandable.
Solid idea.  Will do.
The comment is necessary as the usage is obvious.
I'd inline this into the usage.  I don't think the comment isn't really necessary here, and this code is really only following the lower in the config class.
(nit) static import SECONDS
Is the ThreadContextClassLoader required here?  I don't think anything inside of this method uses a special class loader.
Not strictly, no I don't think so.  Original implementation did not include this, but honestly I added it after reviewing the LDAPAuthenticator.
I don't think this will be helpful in a production server.  I would remove this message

Had it there for a couple of reasons.  First is simply to ensure the cache was working as expected, so you're right, definitely not a production need.  The second is that at Salesforce we are using multiple authentication options, so that users can login either via credentials we store in a password file, or through another custom mechanism we wrote, or via their Salesforce credentials.  This is a little bit of a crude audit mechanism, though clearly very crude.
Happy to remove it, or is it acceptable to change to debug?
(nit) static import createStaticBodyGenerator.  The factory methods that are named createFullClassName are designed to be static imported`
(nit) We don't use final on local variables in Presto

Instead of allowing all 2xx responses, I would check the actual response that Salesforce sends.  In this case, I would guess that the only valid response is 200.  If so, I would inline statusCode variable.
You're right.  Response should be 200.

Exception is a bit broad, and will result in a runtime exception wrapped in a runtime exception.  Instead I would use:
catch (ParserConfigurationException | SAXException | IOException  e) {
I would just inline this and drop the comment.  We can fix this later if it becomes an issue.
Is there any reason to not have the default be "all"?
Also rename to allowedOrganizations

Good idea on the rename.
I originally had the default just implicitly be "all", but @lhofhansl strongly suggested that we require admins to set this explicitly.  I agree, and not just cause he's my boss.  I actually raised the concern about implicitly allowing all orgs, and do in fact prefer the explicit setting.
I would change this to salesforce.allowed-organization, which will make usage more obvious
The XML document encodes this in element "organizationId".  Does Salesforce refer to this as OrgId in the documentation?  Also I don't think the possessive on OrgId is correct.

So, OrgId is commonly used among Salesforce employees and admins.  That stated, it's not found in official documentation I don't think.  I'll change it to Organization Id, and will fix the possessive.

Instead of using a field containing a hard coded unit, use io.airlift.units.Duration.  This is used throughout Presto, so examples should be easy to find.  There is also a MaxDuration annotation that can be used here.
Config should be used for user configuration.  I'd move this constants to the class that uses them, and make them private.
This comment isn't necessary.... there are tons of these config tests in Presto and they all work the same way
Pick values that are extremely unlikely default values... so maybe 111 and 3333.
These two fields can be constants.
This technique for enabling full integration tests doesn't look like other tests in Presto I have seen.  I could be wrong, but I would look at the other tests and copy the techniques.

Presto runs test in parallel with multiple threads, and I don't think this is thread safe.
I suggest removing all of the fields here and up, and just using local variables.
You can wrapper all of these with emptyToNull to simplify the usages
this form username.length() == 0 should be replaced with username.isEmpty(). Your IDE should be making this suggestion for you automatically.
Didn't get any hint on it from IntelliJ, but will research perhaps why.  I've replaced all these checks with emptyToNull as suggested.  These checks are out of old habit.  I should form new habits.
(nit) removed unused variable principal
(nit) I don't think we use underscores in method names in Presto
(nit) Add underscores to the names to the spell checker in the ID doesn't complain
This isn't used
This can be private
Originally didn't depend on the annotations for validation, and therefore used this throughout the package.  I've refactored to use @MaxDuration per your suggestion.
Since we are interpolating into XML let's run the values through Guava's xml excape method: https://guava.dev/releases/20.0/api/docs/com/google/common/xml/XmlEscapers.html
you can use allowedOrganizations.equals(ImmutableList.of("all") &&.  Also, for the style, I believe we put the && on the end of the line.
I'd use 1h here instead
This should not be named -seconds now that we are using Duration since duration can be any unit.
style: we don't use final on local variables (or parameters)
Consider static importing the response code and media types

Let's go with Expire time in for an entry in cache since last write. The description should not include the default value.  The default is printed separately during setup, and the airlift config system has a way to override the defaults.  Also, I don't think we include the max in any descriptions.
